The Census Bureau is shortening its deadline for households to complete the 2020 Census Survey. The due date is now September 30, after it was previously extended to October 31, when the pandemic struck.

District 91 encourages all our residents to complete the 2020 Census. This is your opportunity to help shape the future of Forest Park. A complete count of every person living in Forest Park has tremendous benefits for all District 91 families and community members.

Remember, the U.S. Census serves as the basis for distributing federal assistance to schools and educational institutions, including the National School Lunch Program and special education grants to states. In fact, the U.S. Census determines the distribution of more the $675 billion in federal funds annually to states, counties and communities to support resources such as schools, hospitals and fire departments.

It only takes a few minutes to shape your future. Complete the 2020 Census today! Go to https://2020census.gov/en.html.

District 91

Betsy Ross teachers, staff and students unite...at a safe distance!

On Friday, April 17, 2020, Betsy Ross Primary School hosted a car parade in front of the building at 1315 Marengo Avenue to celebrate the special bond between teachers and staff and their students.

Braving the elements (it snowed that morning!), Principal Bill Milnamow and BR teachers and staff stood out in front of the school (a safe distance apart!) holding signs that showed how much they missed their classes.

In return, parents and their children drove by honking horns, waving, shouting and holding up signs to show their love for their teachers and staff. It was a bittersweet moment for everyone that day as Governor Pritzker prepared to announce that all schools in Illinois would be closed for the remainder of the year.

To see all the parade photos go to: https://www.fpsd91.org/domain/596.

Garfield 2nd Grader Breaks Reading Record!

Super reader Phoebe Thompson, a 2nd grader in Mrs. Goldenberg's class, clocked over 10,000 Read-a-thon minutes during this past school year, more than any student has ever accomplished.

"Every Friday, I gave my students a Read-a-thon paper," explains Mrs. Goldenberg. "Students were asked to log in their reading minutes at home each night during the week and return the paper the next Friday. Every student's Read-a-thon minutes were accumulated and put on report cards."

Every student who read the minimum of 75 minutes per week (2,550 minutes for the year), had their paper signed by a parent or adult and turned it in on time received a colored circle sticker to put on the class bubble gum machine poster and a piece of bubble gum.

Phoebe, who likes to read books about animals and adventure stories, broke the existing record in March and went on to read over 10,020 minutes, or 167 hours! Congratulations, Phoebe on a job well done!

2019 State of the District Address

On Wednesday evening, May 15, 2019, Superintendent Dr. Louis Cavallo and Assistant Superintendent for Operations, Mr. Edward Brophy, presented the FY 2019 year in review. The audience included parents, Board members, administrators and Mayor Rory Hoskins.

Dr. Cavallo reviewed the District mission and vision statements and the core values, covered the extensive work done to date on the National Equity Project and the District's new Equity Imperative and discussed the innovative instruction strategies for improving math scores at all grade levels. Mr. Brophy reported on the District's positive financial situation.

The gymnasium was filled with parents and students who were treated to a wonderful performance of The Sound of Silence, a book by Katrina Goldsaito and illustrated by Julia Kuo. The music for the Reader's Musical Theater Production was arranged by third grade students and music teacher Meeghan Binder.

The program, which included singing, dancing, and the playing of instruments to the pages of the book shown on a large overhead screen, featured all of the third grade classes. The second graders, many of whom moved to the beat of the music, were absolutely fascinated by the performances, which ended with the Field-Stevenson school song.

Afterwards, Dr. Tiffany Brunson, principal of Field-Stevenson, took questions from the second graders who all wanted to know what it was like to be a Shark!

District 91 invites all Forest Park families to march with us in the 23rd annual Forest Park Chamber of Commerce St. Patrick's Day Parade! Saturday, March 2, at 1pm. Walk the route or ride on the school bus. Space on the bus is limited! The staging area is Van Buren between Des Plaines and Madison. Access to the staging area is only allowed from Des Plaines Avenue. Be at the yellow school bus NO LATER THAN NOON! For more information contact Scott Dunnell at 708-710-3898 or email sdunnell@fpsd91.org.

post_text: A big thank you to our students, teachers, administrators, retailers and partners for making Kindness Week such a huge success! All District 91 students, at every grade level, participated in Project Kindness through art, music, classroom lessons, social service projects and community engagement. Over 30 businesses all along Madison Street supported Project Kindness by distributing over 10,000 student-designed labels to their customers. And this was the first time in the history of Forest Park a week in the village was given an official name! We look forward to Project Kindness 2020!

Garfield Spreads Kindness to Others! 🥰

Kindergarten, first grade and second grade students all worked together to spread kindness by making and distributing Survival Kits to the Forest Park Fire and Police Departments. Each survival kit held candies special kindness sayings and said "You are a Hero!" The bags also had #BeKind from the students at Garfield School. The survival kits were packed by Kindergarten and second graders and delivered by the first graders, who took tours of the police and fire departments. 😊

post_text: On Wednesday, February 6, 2019, the District Office had a fun visit from the kindergarten classes at Garfield School. The students, who created unique Valentine cards, walked over from Garfield with their teachers and instructional aides to pick up the cards that were stamped by the District Office. After a quick tour, the students were on their way to the Post Office to mail their special cards in time for Valentine's Day! What a wonderful way to show kindness!!
